title-group.article-title: Vibration signature analysis of a high speed rotor supported on ball bearings due to localized defects

article-meta.aff: 1Mechanical Engineering Discipline, PDPM Indian Institute of Information Technology, Design and Manufacturing Jabalpur, India
2Mechanical and Industrial Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Roorkee, India

author-notes.corresp: PK Kankar, Mechanical Engineering Discipline, PDPM Indian Institute of Information Technology, Design and Manufacturing Jabalpur, Jabalpur, India Email: pavankankar@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper presents the vibration signature analysis of the high speed rolling element bearings due to localized defects with an un-cracked and a cracked rotor. In rotating machines, one of the main causes of breakdown is faults in ball bearings and crack in rotors. Thus, accurate prediction of severe vibration conditions and characteristic defect frequencies is crucial for the reliable operation. A test rig of a high speed rotor supported on healthy and defective ball bearings is used. The vibration response is obtained and analyzed for the un-cracked and cracked rotor with and without defects on bearing components. The defects such as spalls on the outer race, inner race and on the rolling elements are considered for the study. Combined parametric effects have been analyzed to predict the dynamic response of a rotor-bearing system using response surface method. It is also observed that the severe vibrations occur under bearings with spall on the inner race surface and on a ball under high speed rotor condition.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Rolling element bearings are used in a wide variety of rotating machinery from small hand-held devices to heavy duty industrial systems and are the primary cause of breakdowns in machines. Vibration measurements are widely used for fault detection in rotating machines. The importance of early prediction of severe vibration conditions and characteristic defect frequencies has led to continuous efforts due to the fact that unpredictable occurrence of damage may cause disastrous failure. Also, severe vibration can generate noise and degrade the quality of a product line. The vibrations are generated by geometrical imperfections on the individual bearing components and these imperfections are caused by irregularities during the manufacturing process as well as wear and tear. Rolling bearings defects may be categorized as point or local defects and distributed defects. Surface roughness, waviness, misaligned races and off-size rolling elements are included in the class of distributed defects. The localized defects include cracks, pits and spalls caused by fatigue on the rolling surfaces (Tandon and Choudhury, 1997). The vibration signals contain information on defective parts and a variety of vibration-based techniques have been developed to monitor the condition of rotor bearing systems. Vibration signals are analyzed using time domain analysis, frequency domain analysis and time-frequency domain analysis (wavelet). Faults are classified using various artificial intelligence techniques i.e. artificial neural networks (ANN) (Alguindigue et al., 1993; McCormick and Nandi, 1997; Tse and Atherton, 1999; Kankar et al., 2011a), support vector machine (SVM) (Jack and Nandi, 2002; Samanta et al., 2003; Sugumaran et al., 2007; Hu et al., 2007), fuzzy logic classifiers (Wang et al., 2004a,b) and other soft computing techniques to predict the meaningful results from the observations. In these works after a vibration signal is measured, different signal processing techniques are employed to extract the fault sensitive features to serve as the monitoring indices. Then these techniques are used to diagnose various bearing faults from the vibration signature obtained.

McFadden and Smith (1984, 1985) have developed the models for vibration produced by a single and multiple point defects on the inner race of the rolling element bearing under radial load based on high-frequency resonance technique. Harsha et al. (2006) developed an analytical model to investigate nonlinear vibrations of a rotor bearing system due to distributed defect on the ball. Liang et al. (2007) utilized RSM to analyze the effect of design parameters on the sound radiation from a vibrating panel. They showed that information about RSM can give the direction of design modification, such as the weight of material and the thickness of thin panel etc. Kankar et al. (2009) have applied response surface methodology (RSM), to investigate the effects of distributed defects on the nonlinear vibrations of a rotor bearing system. Kankar et al. (2011b) have proposed fault diagnosis methodology for rolling element bearings, which utilizes autocorrelation of raw vibration signals to reduce the dimension of vibration signals with minimal loss of significant frequency content.

Condition monitoring based on vibration measurement is mainly emphasized in signal processing techniques and diagnosis of defects based on vibration signature. The present study aims to identify the effect of various bearing component faults with un-cracked/ cracked rotor condition on the stability and dynamic behavior of the rotor bearing system. Defects in bearing components are considered as spalls on the outer race, inner race and ball. In this paper, severe vibration conditions are determined by approximating amplitude of vibration using a series of polynomials using RSM. Experiments are carried out for healthy bearings and defective bearings with un-cracked and cracked rotor. The flow chart used for analysis using RSM is as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
The flow chart of response surface method.

sec.title: 2. Response surface method
sec.p: Response surface methodology was invented by Box and Wilson in 1951. This methodology is a collection of mathematical and statistical techniques that are useful for modeling and analysis in applications where a response interest is influenced by several variables and the objective is to optimize this response. The selection of appropriate model and the development of response surface models have been carried out using statistical software, Design Expert. RSM can take unknown response function and approximate it by coded variables where these coded variables are usually defined to be dimensionless with zero mean and the same spread or standard deviation. Usually a low order polynomial in some relatively small region of the independent variable space is generated. RSM has found extensive application in a wide variety of industrial settings such as chemical processes, semiconductor and electronics manufacturing, machining, metal cutting, and joining processes etc (Myers and Montgomery, 1995). The input variables are sometimes called independent variables or factors, and the performance measures or quality characteristics are known as responses. For the most response surface, the relationship between the response variable of interest (y) and the factors (x1, x2, … , xk) can be described in the following second-order equation. (1)y=f(x)=βo+∑i=1 nβixi+∑i=1 nβiixi 2+∑i=1,j>1 nβijxixj+ɛ Where ɛ represents the noise or error observed in the response y, β is polynomial coefficient, and n is number of factors. The equation can also be expressed in matrix form as (2)Y=XB+ɛ

The method of least squares is used to estimate the polynomial coefficients in the approximating polynomials such that minimizes the sum of squares of the model errors. Then matrix B of polynomial coefficients can be obtained from the formula (3)B= (XTX )-1XTY

The response surface analysis is done in terms of the fitted surface. Once a response surface model is obtained, statistical analysis techniques i.e. analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used to check the fitness of the model.

sec.title: 3. Experimental setup
sec.p:
Rolling element bearings are of paramount importance to almost all forms of rotating machinery. Predicting the severe vibration conditions due to localized defects in bearings with un-cracked/ cracked rotor is extremely important in industries to fully utilize the machine production capacity and to reduce the plant downtime. In the present work, a simple test rig as shown in Figure 2 is used with a rotor supported on SKF 6205 ball bearings. Various parameters of bearings used for the study are listed in Table 1. Data are recorded for healthy bearings and bearings with spall on the outer race, inner race and rolling element using an un-cracked rotor and a cracked rotor. Response analysis is carried out under the effects of the localized defects of bearings. The design of experiments is employed to establish the parametric relationship among the performance characteristics of bearings. Figure 2.
Experimental setup with defective and non-defective bearings.
Table 1.
Details of rotor and bearing used for experimentation
Parameter Value
Bearing specs 6205
Outer race diameter (D) 52 mm
Inner race diameter (d) 25 mm
Ball diameter (db) 7.93 mm
Number of balls (Nb) 8
Contact angle 0°
Mass of rotor (m) 1.93 kg
Radial load (W) 19.3 N

sec.title: 3.1. Surface defects
sec.p:
Spalls, pits and dents are the major forms of bearing damage. Fatigue cracking of the surface occurs when the repeatedly cycled stress on one surface in rolling contact with another, exceeds the endurance strength of the material. This defect propagates and results in a large pit or spall on the surface of bearing components. Corrosion and oxidation pits, true/false brinnelling and hard particle contamination dents act as locations for incipient fatigue. This can cause bearing endurance to be shorter than that designed and may also lead to rapid failure of the bearing. In this paper, a defect (spall) has been considered on the outer race, inner race and rolling element as shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Bearing components with defect. (a) Outer Race with spall (b) Inner Race with spall (c) Ball with spall.

sec.title: 3.2. Response surface model establishment
sec.p:
This procedure begins with the identification of factors that affect the stability of the rotor bearing system. Each parameter affects the nature of the response in mutual interactions with other parameters as well as with separate factors. Bearing loaders are provided essentially to analyze the effect of bending load on the un-cracked and the cracked shaft at different speeds. Loaders can provide the necessary radial load to excite bearing faults sufficiently to increase the spectral amplitude. The faulted bearing is installed in the inboard bearing housing. Accelerometers are installed in vertical and horizontal directions on the motor and two bearing housings. The crack induced in the shaft is from using Electrical Discharge Machining (Figure 4). Figure 4.
Crack in the shaft using Electrical Discharge Machining.
Figure 5.
Vibration signals for various bearing conditions at 1000 RPM with un-cracked rotor. (a) Healthy bearings (b) Bearing with spall in outer race (c) Bearing with spall on inner race (d) Ball with spall (e) Combined bearing components defects.

The following bearing component faults are considered with un-cracked and cracked rotor conditions as factors that are influencing responses, which are taken as peaks of vibration response in horizontal and vertical direction.
Spall on outer race (Figure 3(a))
Spall on inner race (Figure 3(b))
Ball with spall and (Figure 3(c))
Speed of rotor

These four factors are selected with two levels using un-cracked and cracked rotor. The upper and lower levels of each factor are defined in Table 2. In order to perform DOE to determine the condition that gives the chaotic vibration (maximum noise) conditions, experiments are carried out in 20 trials with different set of bearings as listed in Table 3. These trials consider various combinations of defects in bearing components. Trial 5, 10, 15 and 20 are for the combined bearing components defect at different speeds and rotor conditions. Combined bearing components defects correspond to the bearing with defects in all its components, i.e. outer race, inner race and ball defect. Table 2.
Parameters for Design of Experiment
Parameter designation symbols Parameters Minimum level (−) Maximum level (+)
A Outer race with spall 0 3 mm
B Inner race with spall 0 2 mm
C Ball with spall 0 4 mm
D Speed of rotor 1000 rpm 5000 rpm
E Rotor condition Un-cracked Cracked
Table 3.

Assuming no slip and considering the outer race to be stationary, the general forms of the bearing defect frequency equations are given as:
Cage rotational frequency ωcage=ωin (1-dDcos(α) )2
Inner race defect frequency or wave passage frequency of inner race ωwpi=Nbωin (1+dDcos(α) )2
Outer race defect frequency or ball passage frequency ωBP=Nbωin (1-dDcos(α) )2
Ball spin frequency or wave passage frequency of ball ωwpb=ωin2Dd (1- (dDcos(α) )2 ) where ωin is rotational frequency of the inner race, d is the ball diameter, D is the pitch diameter, Nb is the number of rolling elements and α is the contact angle.
When the rolling element set and the cage rotates with a constant angular velocity, a parametrically excited vibration is generated and transmitted through the outer race. The characteristic frequency of this vibration is called the varying compliance frequency (VC) and is given as:
Varying Compliance frequency (VC) Nb X ωcage
The bearing frequency equations provide a theoretical estimation of the frequencies to be expected when various defects occur on the bearing elements.

sec.title: 4. Results and discussions
sec.p: The vibration response plots for un-cracked and cracked rotors at 1000 and 5000 rpm with healthy and defective bearings have been shown in the form of frequency spectra as shown in Figures 5 to 8, respectively. Figure 5 shows the response plots for an un-cracked rotor without and with localized defects on bearing components at rotor speed 1000 rpm. For healthy bearings, peak amplitude of vibration excitation appears at varying compliance frequency (VC; 53 Hz) and its multiples in frequency spectra as shown in Figure 5(a). In the presence of spall on the outer race, the peak amplitude of vibration appears in the spectrum at ball passage frequency (ωBP; 53 Hz), (3ωBP; 159 Hz), (4ωBP − 2ωcage; 199 Hz) and (4(ωBP − ωcage); 186 Hz) as shown in Figure 5 (b). Figure 5(c) shows the response with spall on inner race. For this trial peak, the peak amplitude of vibration appears in the response at harmonics of wave passage frequency (2ωwpi/3; 53 Hz) and (2ωwpi − ωin; 144 Hz). The next trial is considered with spall on the ball. Exciting frequency appears at wave passage frequency (ωwpb; 40 Hz) and its harmonics in frequency spectra as shown in Figure 5(d). When spall exists in all bearing components, the peak amplitude of vibration appears at wave passage frequency of the ball (ωwpb; 40 Hz) and superharmonics of wave passage frequency of inner race (3ωwpi; 240 Hz) as shown in Figure 5(e).

Vibration responses of a balanced un-cracked rotor supported on healthy and faulty bearings at 5000 rpm have been observed as shown in Figure 6. When ball bearings without any defect have been taken, the peak excitation occurs at Varying Compliance (VC; 265 Hz) frequency, (VC − 3ωcage; 166 Hz) and (2VC − 3ωcage; 431 Hz), mainly due to parametric excitation as shown in Figure 6 (a), while bearing with outer race defect shown the peak excitation in vibration spectra at ball passage frequency (ωBP; 265 Hz) and its harmonics as shown in Figure 6 (b). The spall on bearing’s inner race excites the vibration spectra as an interaction between wave passage frequency (ωwpi; 401 Hz) and rotational frequency of inner race (ωin; 83.33 Hz) at ((ωwpi + ωin)/2; 242 Hz) as shown in Figure 6(c). Bearing with defect in ball shown the peak excitation in vibration spectra as an interaction of wave passage frequency (ωwpb; 196 Hz) and cage frequency (ωcage; 33 Hz) at (ωwpb + 2ωcage; 263 Hz) as shown in Figure 6 (d). Figure 6(e) shows the frequency spectrum of bearing with spall exist in all bearing components. The peak amplitude of vibration appears as an interaction between wave passage frequency of inner race (ωwpi; 401 Hz) and rotational frequency of inner race (ωin; 83.33 Hz) at ((ωwpi + ωin)/2; 242 Hz). Figure 6.
Vibration signals for various bearing conditions at 5000 RPM with un-cracked rotor. (a) Healthy bearings (b) Bearing with spall in outer race (c) Bearing with spall on inner race (d) Ball with spall (e) Combined bearing components defects.

Figure 7 shows the response plots for a cracked rotor without and with localized defects on bearing components at rotor speed 1000 rpm. Peak amplitude of vibration excitation for healthy bearings appears at varying compliance frequency (VC; 53 Hz), its multiples and its interaction with rotational frequency (X; 16 Hz) in frequency spectra as shown in Figure 7(a). In the presence of spall on the outer race, the peak amplitude of vibration appears in the spectrum at the ball passage frequency (ωBP; 53 Hz), (3ωBP − X; 143 Hz) and (5ωBP + X; 282 Hz) as shown in Figure 7(b). Figure 7(c) shows the response with spall on the inner race. The peak amplitude of vibration appears for this trial at harmonics of wave passage frequency (2ωwpi; 160 Hz) and ((ωwpi + X); 97 Hz). The next trial is considered with spall on the ball. Exciting frequency appears at harmonics of wave passage frequency (4ωwpb; 157 Hz and 8ωwpb; 314 Hz) and at harmonics of rotational frequency (3X; 50 Hz) in frequency spectra as shown in Figure 7(d). For the bearing with spall in all of its components, the peak amplitude of vibration appears as an interaction between wave passage frequency of the inner race and rotational frequency at (2ωwpi − X; 144 Hz) and (ωwpi + X; 97 Hz) as shown in Figure 7(e). Figure 7.
Vibration signals for various bearing conditions at 1000 RPM with cracked rotor. (a) Healthy bearings (b) Bearing with spall in outer race (c) Bearing with spall on inner race (d) Ball with spall (e) Combined bearing components defects. Figure 8.
Vibration signals for various bearing conditions at 5000 RPM with cracked rotor. (a) Healthy bearings (b) Bearing with spall in outer race (c) Bearing with spall on inner race (d) Ball with spall (e) Combined bearing components defects.

When the cracked rotor is supported on bearings at 5000 rpm speed without any defect considered, the peak excitation occurs at Varying Compliance (VC; 265 Hz) frequency and at rotational frequency (X; 83 Hz), mainly due to parametric excitation and due to crack on the rotor surface as shown in Figure 8(a), while the bearing with the outer race defect shows the peak excitation in vibration spectra at (ωBP; 265 Hz), ((ωBP − X)/2; 91 Hz) and (ωBP − X; 182 Hz) as shown in Figure 8(b). The other defect in bearing components as inner race and balls with cracked rotor excites the vibration spectra at specific frequencies at ((ωwpi + ωin)/2; 242 Hz), (ωwpb + 2ωcage; 263 Hz) and at rotational frequency (X; 83 Hz) respectively, as shown in Figure 8(c) and 8(d). In the presence of combined bearing components defects, the peak amplitude of vibration appears as an interaction between wave passage frequency of ball and cage frequency at (ωwpb + 2ωcage; 263 Hz) and at (X; 83 Hz) as shown in Figure 8(e)

Table 3 shows levels of various factors with corresponding vibration response. Through the experiments, the polynomial f(x) is approximated by the design parameters (A, B, C and D). The final functions of the response surface model are shown in equations (4) to (7), which are listed below.

sec.title: 4.1. Horizontal response
sec.p: The approximated polynomial for horizontal acceleration response is:

sec.title: 4.2. Vertical response
sec.p: The approximated polynomial for vertical acceleration response is:

sec.title: Cracked rotor
sec.p:
The performance prediction of vibration amplitude in horizontal and vertical displacement response is shown in Figure 9. The actual and predicted values of response in both directions are very close and verify the fitness of the polynomial for response. Figure 9.
The performance prediction. (a) Horizontal; (b) Vertical displacement response.

In order to verify whether the obtained polynomials are valuable or not, we performed a variance analysis and F-ratio test on them. Table 4 shows analysis of variance table for horizontal displacement. The Model F-value of 65.84 implies the model is significant and valuable. Values of “p-value” less than 0.0500 indicate model terms are significant. In this case A, D, BDE and CDE are significant model terms. Values greater than 0.1000 indicate the model terms are not significant. Analysis of variance for vertical displacement is shown in Table 5. The model F-value of 2218.56 shows that the model is significant. In this case all terms except AE are significant model terms, since AE has a “p-value” greater than 0.1. Table 4.

After testing the polynomials using ANOVA, the polynomials developed are used to analyze the relation between factors and their corresponding responses. The RSM of horizontal and vertical acceleration responses are developed with un-cracked and cracked rotor.

sec.title: 4.3. Response surfaces (Horizontal)
sec.p:
Response surfaces in Figures 10(a), (b) and (c) show interaction effects of defects present in the outer race, inner race and ball with the speed of the rotor respectively, on horizontal response for an un-cracked rotor condition. Amplitude of vibration increases with inner race defect, ball defect and speed. The peak amplitude of vibration decreases when the outer race defect is present simultaneously with the inner race defect or the ball defect as shown in Figures 10(a) and (b). This decrease in amplitude is due to “self-peening” of the bearing defects and it indicates that catastrophic stage of bearing started [Orhan et al., 2006]. The response surface in Figure 10(d) shows that the amplitude of vibration increases due to ball defect and inner race defect. Figures 10(c), (e), (f) show the interaction effect of speed with outer race defect, inner race defect and ball defect respectively and indicate that the speed of the rotor has a more significant effect on the amplitude of vibration. Figure 10.
Response surfaces (horizontal) for un-cracked rotor showing interaction of (a) Parameter A and B; (b) Parameter A and C; (c) Parameter A and D; (d) Parameter B and C; (e) Parameter B and D; (f) Parameter C and D.

The response surfaces in Figure 11 show the interaction effect of various factors with each other, on the horizontal response for a cracked rotor condition. The response surface in Figure 11(a) shows the interaction of outer race defect with inner race defect. Amplitude of vibration increases in the presence of the individual defect, i.e. either of the outer race defect or the inner race defects, but when both the effects present simultaneously because of “self-peening” of the bearing flaws, the amplitude of vibration decreases. Figure 11(b) and (d) show that for the cracked rotor condition, ball defect has a significant effect on the vibration response as compared with the outer race defect and the inner race defect. Response surfaces in Figure 11(c), (e), and (f) show the interaction effect of the speed of the rotor with the outer race defect, inner race defect and ball defect respectively and indicate that the speed of the rotor has a more significant effect on amplitude of vibration. Figure 11(f) also indicates that for an upper level of speed of the rotor and the ball defect, the amplitude of vibration increases considerably. Figure 11.
Response surfaces (horizontal) for cracked rotor showing interaction of (a) Parameter A and B; (b) Parameter A and C; (c) Parameter A and D; (d) Parameter B and C; (e) Parameter B and D; (f) Parameter C and D.

sec.title: 4.4. Response surfaces (vertical)
sec.p:
Response surfaces in Figures 12 and 13 show the interaction effect of various factors with each other on the vertical response for un-cracked and cracked rotor conditions. Interaction effects of bearing component defects on each other are as shown in Figure 12(a), (b) and (d) and Figure 13(a), (b) and (d) for un-cracked rotor condition and cracked rotor condition respectively. These indicate that in the presence of defects in bearing components simultaneously, the bearing enters into a catastrophic stage and there is chance of false prediction because of a decrease in amplitude. It is also shown that the ball defect has a significant effect on vibration response as compared with outer race defect and inner race defect. Figure 12(c), (e) and (f) and Figure 13(c), (e) and (f) show the interaction effect of speed with outer race defect, inner race defect and ball defect respectively and indicate that the speed of the rotor has a more significant effect on the amplitude of vibration. Severe (chaotic) vibrations are observed in the vibration spectrum, mainly because of the ball defect and rotor speed in the horizontal and vertical response under cracked and un-cracked rotor condition. Hence, from the discussion it is clear that due to the ball waviness and internal radial clearance chaotic vibrations appear in the spectrum. Figure 12.
Response surfaces (vertical) for un-cracked rotor showing interaction of (a) Parameter A and B; (b) Parameter A and C; (c) Parameter A and D; (d) Parameter B and C; (e) Parameter B and D; (f) Parameter C and D.
Figure 13.
Response surfaces (vertical) for cracked rotor showing interaction of (a) Parameter A and B; (b) Parameter A and C; (c) Parameter A and D; (d) Parameter B and C; (e) Parameter B and D; (f) Parameter C and D.

The response surface model generated in equations 4 to 7 can further be used to discover the conditions of the low amplitude of vibrations. This approach is sometimes called an inverse approach because it is based on the output desired, and input parameters are estimated that lead to such outputs (Cundy, 2003). Design-Expert software’s (Anderson and Whitcomb, 2004) numerical optimization is used to minimize horizontal and vertical amplitude of vibration. Numerical simulation is carried out by considering multi response optimization. Results obtained by numerical optimization are shown in Figures 14 and 15 for un-cracked and cracked rotor conditions respectively. For the un-cracked rotor, results show that the minimum amplitude of vibration (horizontal amplitude = 0.002788 gRMS and vertical amplitude = 0.015926) is obtained for the bearing with outer race defect = 3.00 mm, inner race defect = 1.47 mm and ball defect = 2.40 mm as shown in Figure 14. Figure 15 shows a contour plot for the cracked rotor with optimal conditions. The results show that the minimum amplitude of vibration (horizontal amplitude = 0.020482 gRMS and vertical amplitude = 0.013113) is obtained in the absence of an outer race defect on the bearing, with an inner race defect = 1.78 mm and a ball defect = 4.00 mm on the bearing. Figure 14.
Contour plot at optimal condition for un-cracked rotor with outer race defect = 3.00 mm, inner race defect = 1.47 mm, ball defect = 2.40mm, rotor speed = 1000.01 rpm, horizontal amplitude = 0.002788 gRMS and vertical amplitude = 0.015926 gRMS.
Figure 15.
Contour plot at optimal condition for cracked rotor with outer race defect = 0.00 mm, iInner race defect = 1.78 mm, ball defect = 4.00 mm, rotor speed = 1000.00 rpm, horizontal amplitude = 0.020482 gRMS and vertical amplitude = 0.013113 gRMS.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p:
In the present investigation, a test rig of a high speed rotor supported on localized defected ball bearings has been used. The vibration response is obtained and analyzed for an un-cracked rotor and a cracked rotor with and without defects in bearing components. Defects such as spalls on the outer race, inner race and on rolling elements are considered for the study. Combined parametric effects have been analyzed to predict the dynamic response of a rotor-bearing system using a response surface method. From the obtained responses the following conclusions have been drawn:
Severe vibration (maximum peak of vibration excitation) occurs in the case of a bearing with an inner race defect at a rotor speed of 5000 rpm as shown in trial 8 (Table 3) under an un-cracked rotor condition. For the cracked rotor, the maximum amplitude of vibration observed due to a ball defect at 5000 rpm is as shown in trial 19 (Table 3) (for horizontal responses).
Severe vibration (maximum peak of vibration excitation) occurs in the case of a bearing with a ball defect at 5000 rpm under an un-cracked and cracked rotor conditions as shown in trial 9 and trial 19 (Table 3) (for vertical responses).
Vibration responses due to interaction in an outer race defect and an inner race defect reduces as shown in Figure 10(a), 11(a), 12(a) and 13(a). This indicates that a catastrophic stage of bearing started and is due to “self-peening” of the bearing defects, and amplitude levels decreased
Vibration responses under an un-cracked rotor condition, due to interaction in inner race defect and ball defect, increase (for horizontal responses) as shown in Figure 10(d), while these responses decrease (for vertical responses) as shown in Figure 12(d).
Vibration responses under a cracked rotor condition, due to interaction in inner race defect and ball defect, decrease (for vertical responses) as shown in Figure 13(d), while not much of a significant effect has been observed on these responses as shown in Figure 11(d) (for horizontal responses).
Results also show that the approach proposed can be effectively used for damage analysis for the reduction in amplitude.
